randm.c

00033 
00034 #include "ppp.h"
00035 #include "md5.h"
00036 #include "randm.h"
00037 
00038 #include "pppdebug.h"
00039 
00040 
00041 #if MD5_SUPPORT>0   /* this module depends on MD5 */
00042 #define RANDPOOLSZ 16   /* Bytes stored in the pool of randomness. */
00043 
00044 /*****************************/
00045 /*** LOCAL DATA STRUCTURES ***/
00046 /*****************************/
00047 static char randPool[RANDPOOLSZ];   /* Pool of randomness. */
00048 static long randCount = 0;      /* Pseudo-random incrementer */
00049 
00050 
00051 /***********************************/
00052 /*** PUBLIC FUNCTION DEFINITIONS ***/
00053 /***********************************/
00054 /*
00055  * Initialize the random number generator.
00056  *
00057  * Since this is to be called on power up, we don't have much
00058  *  system randomess to work with.  Here all we use is the
00059  *  real-time clock.  We'll accumulate more randomness as soon
00060  *  as things start happening.
00061  */
00062 void avRandomInit()
00063 {
00064     avChurnRand(NULL, 0);
00065 }
00066 
00067 /*
00068  * Churn the randomness pool on a random event.  Call this early and often
00069  *  on random and semi-random system events to build randomness in time for
00070  *  usage.  For randomly timed events, pass a null pointer and a zero length
00071  *  and this will use the system timer and other sources to add randomness.
00072  *  If new random data is available, pass a pointer to that and it will be
00073  *  included.
00074  *
00075  * Ref: Applied Cryptography 2nd Ed. by Bruce Schneier p. 427
00076  */
00077 void avChurnRand(char *randData, u32_t randLen)
00078 {
00079     MD5_CTX md5;
00080 
00081 /*  ppp_trace(LOG_INFO, "churnRand: %u@%P\n", randLen, randData); */
00082     MD5Init(&md5);
00083     MD5Update(&md5, (u_char *)randPool, sizeof(randPool));
00084     if (randData)
00085         MD5Update(&md5, (u_char *)randData, randLen);
00086     else {
00087         struct {
00088             /* INCLUDE fields for any system sources of randomness */
00089             char foobar;
00090         } sysData;
00091 
00092         /* Load sysData fields here. */
00093         ;
00094         MD5Update(&md5, (u_char *)&sysData, sizeof(sysData));
00095     }
00096     MD5Final((u_char *)randPool, &md5);
00097 /*  ppp_trace(LOG_INFO, "churnRand: -> 0\n"); */
00098 }
00099 
00100 /*
00101  * Use the random pool to generate random data.  This degrades to pseudo
00102  *  random when used faster than randomness is supplied using churnRand().
00103  * Note: It's important that there be sufficient randomness in randPool
00104  *  before this is called for otherwise the range of the result may be
00105  *  narrow enough to make a search feasible.
00106  *
00107  * Ref: Applied Cryptography 2nd Ed. by Bruce Schneier p. 427
00108  *
00109  * XXX Why does he not just call churnRand() for each block?  Probably
00110  *  so that you don't ever publish the seed which could possibly help
00111  *  predict future values.
00112  * XXX Why don't we preserve md5 between blocks and just update it with
00113  *  randCount each time?  Probably there is a weakness but I wish that
00114  *  it was documented.
00115  */
00116 void avGenRand(char *buf, u32_t bufLen)
00117 {
00118     MD5_CTX md5;
00119     u_char tmp[16];
00120     u32_t n;
00121 
00122     while (bufLen > 0) {
00123         n = LWIP_MIN(bufLen, RANDPOOLSZ);
00124         MD5Init(&md5);
00125         MD5Update(&md5, (u_char *)randPool, sizeof(randPool));
00126         MD5Update(&md5, (u_char *)&randCount, sizeof(randCount));
00127         MD5Final(tmp, &md5);
00128         randCount++;
00129         memcpy(buf, tmp, n);
00130         buf += n;
00131         bufLen -= n;
00132     }
00133 }
00134 
00135 /*
00136  * Return a new random number.
00137  */
00138 u32_t avRandom()
00139 {
00140     u32_t newRand;
00141 
00142     avGenRand((char *)&newRand, sizeof(newRand));
00143 
00144     return newRand;
00145 }
00146 
00147 #else /* MD5_SUPPORT */
00148 
00149 
00150 /*****************************/
00151 /*** LOCAL DATA STRUCTURES ***/
00152 /*****************************/
00153 static int  avRandomized = 0;       /* Set when truely randomized. */
00154 static u32_t avRandomSeed = 0;      /* Seed used for random number generation. */
00155 
00156 
00157 /***********************************/
00158 /*** PUBLIC FUNCTION DEFINITIONS ***/
00159 /***********************************/
00160 /*
00161  * Initialize the random number generator.
00162  *
00163  * Here we attempt to compute a random number seed but even if
00164  * it isn't random, we'll randomize it later.
00165  *
00166  * The current method uses the fields from the real time clock,
00167  * the idle process counter, the millisecond counter, and the
00168  * hardware timer tick counter.  When this is invoked
00169  * in startup(), then the idle counter and timer values may
00170  * repeat after each boot and the real time clock may not be
00171  * operational.  Thus we call it again on the first random
00172  * event.
00173  */
00174 void avRandomInit()
00175 {
00176 #if 0
00177     /* Get a pointer into the last 4 bytes of clockBuf. */
00178     u32_t *lptr1 = (u32_t *)((char *)&clockBuf[3]);
00179 
00180     /*
00181      * Initialize our seed using the real-time clock, the idle
00182      * counter, the millisecond timer, and the hardware timer
00183      * tick counter.  The real-time clock and the hardware
00184      * tick counter are the best sources of randomness but
00185      * since the tick counter is only 16 bit (and truncated
00186      * at that), the idle counter and millisecond timer
00187      * (which may be small values) are added to help
00188      * randomize the lower 16 bits of the seed.
00189      */
00190     readClk();
00191     avRandomSeed += *(u32_t *)clockBuf + *lptr1 + OSIdleCtr
00192              + ppp_mtime() + ((u32_t)TM1 << 16) + TM1;
00193 #else
00194     avRandomSeed += sys_jiffies(); /* XXX */
00195 #endif
00196         
00197     /* Initialize the Borland random number generator. */
00198     srand((unsigned)avRandomSeed);
00199 }
00200 
00201 /*
00202  * Randomize our random seed value.  Here we use the fact that
00203  * this function is called at *truely random* times by the polling
00204  * and network functions.  Here we only get 16 bits of new random
00205  * value but we use the previous value to randomize the other 16
00206  * bits.
00207  */
00208 void avRandomize(void)
00209 {
00210     static u32_t last_jiffies;
00211 
00212     if (!avRandomized) {
00213         avRandomized = !0;
00214         avRandomInit();
00215         /* The initialization function also updates the seed. */
00216     } else {
00217 /*        avRandomSeed += (avRandomSeed << 16) + TM1; */
00218         avRandomSeed += (sys_jiffies() - last_jiffies); /* XXX */
00219     }
00220     last_jiffies = sys_jiffies();
00221 }
00222 
00223 /*
00224  * Return a new random number.
00225  * Here we use the Borland rand() function to supply a pseudo random
00226  * number which we make truely random by combining it with our own
00227  * seed which is randomized by truely random events. 
00228  * Thus the numbers will be truely random unless there have been no
00229  * operator or network events in which case it will be pseudo random
00230  * seeded by the real time clock.
00231  */
00232 u32_t avRandom()
00233 {
00234     return ((((u32_t)rand() << 16) + rand()) + avRandomSeed);
00235 }
00236 
00237 
00238 
00239 #endif /* MD5_SUPPORT */
